Rabies cases rise in northern Thailand
Dr. Taweechai of the Department of Disease Control said on February 9 that the number of rabies cases in the northeast of Thailand has increased in recent months, with a total of 74 cases.
So far this year (October 2018-September 2019) there have been 67 and 7 cases of rabies in Surin and Buri Ram provinces in the northeast, respectively, for a total of 74.
All of them have been vaccinated against rabies in the past.
He urged people to get their pets vaccinated against rabies and not to touch the saliva of any animals suspected of being infected.
Rabies can be transmitted to humans from cats and bats as well as dogs.
Once a person is infected and develops the disease, it is almost always fatal, but vaccination before the disease develops can prevent death.

FUJI Develops System to Prevent Accidents Caused by Leaving Vehicles | Chubu Economic Newspaper: Economic Information for Aichi, Gifu, Mie, and Shizuoka Prefectures

FUJI (head office in Chiryu City) which manufactures and sells robots for installing electronic components and manufacturing machines, has started developing a system to prevent children from being left behind in cars.
The system is set up so that when a motion sensor detects movement in the car, a notification is sent to the phone or chat.
The company is currently conducting a proof-of-concept experiment using its own shuttle vehicles.
While accidents caused by leaving children behind are also occurring, this system will help to protect children.
Currently, the company is conducting a demonstration experiment using two of their own vehicles for the after-school English conversation program for children, "teracoya THANK" in Chiryu City.
Three temperature sensors that detect human movement from the difference between the human and the surrounding temperature are installed in the ceiling of the car.
If the engine is turned off and the door is closed, and if the movement of people is detected after a certain amount of time has elapsed, an automatic warning notification is sent.
By linking the state and information of the engine and door, it can prevent false detection as much as possible.
The warning notification is sent via the cloud.
In addition to calling the number registered in advance, it will be displayed on the computer or smartphone chat.
You can register multiple addresses, and they have taken care to avoid mistakes such as forgetting to register an address.
The field test will continue until the end of February.
Kantani Ichikawa, head of the second section of the innovation promotion department, pointed out that "during the experiment, issues outside of the system were also seen."
For example, they were able to pick up various challenges related to school buses, such as creating an environment in which drivers can concentrate on driving.
"We will put our all into expanding the solution."
The development of the system to prevent leaving was triggered by a series of accidents involving leaving of buses at pickup points across the country.
Employees with young children suggested that there was nothing that could be done to protect their children's safety.
They decided to develop the system, using the knowledge they had gained from their FA (Factory Automation) related business, such as IoT (Internet of Things) and sensor-based information management.
FUJI's abandonment prevention system is easy to use.
The sensors can be installed by simply pinning them to the ceiling.
Since it can be easily retrofitted to the shuttle bus, it will be easier to introduce and aim for widespread use.
In the future, they will be looking to collaborate with nurseries and kindergartens, as well as considering productization.

With Valentine's Day on February 14th, chocolate prices are rising due to the high cost of raw materials and packaging, but sales of high-priced chocolates for personal use and for family and friends are doing well.
In Fukui Prefecture, local stores and confectionery shops are trying to attract customers by offering products that emphasize local flavor, high quality, and attention to materials.
The Seibu Fukui store (Fukui City) opened a special sales area on the sixth floor on January 25.
Up until the 14th, they have sold 450 types of 40 brands, including 10 confectionery shops in the prefecture.
Sandwiches with chocolate made from Fukui sake and cookies with real chocolate are popular, as well as other products from the same company that include chocolate.
According to the store representative, the retail price of the products has risen by about 10% compared to last year.

"This year's trend is that there are many products that have a distinctive character, such as those that are made with high quality ingredients or have a high-class feel to their packaging. As for consumer trends, it seems that people are buying products for themselves and their families and enjoying them as a treat."
Despite the unfavorable economic conditions, sales of high-priced items are doing well.

"We are focusing on creating a sales floor that allows customers to enjoy the Valentine's Day event itself," the representative said.

The chocolate has a fruity flavor that is rich in cocoa beans and has a low bitterness, and is sold in packs of three for 1,000 yen and nine for 3,000 yen.

"While the culture of giving chocolate as a duty is gradually fading, there is still a demand for Valentine's Day to be a little bit special. [Opinion] Echizen Town is creating an end note and distributing it to residents who wish to receive it.

Last year, when they published the "Okayamibook," which covers the necessary procedures and writing style for a will, and a list of heirs and family trees, they received many requests to receive it for themselves.
There are also workshops on how to write an obituary and how to organize your affairs before you die, and it seems that "end-of-life" has become a common term among the people of the prefecture.
The Echizen town's obituary notebook is 35 pages long.

Chapter 5 begins with a review of their life history, and then they write down their current health status, financial situation, future care needs, wishes for end-of-life medical care, and preferences for funeral and burial.
There are also sections for things they want to do in the rest of their life and messages to important people.
It might break your bones to write 35 pages, but you don't have to fill all of them.
What they want to leave behind for their family and others.
The important thing is to make your intentions clear.
There are many different types of notebooks available in shops that are tailored to your purpose, and it is recommended that you start writing as soon as you can.
It was in 2009 that the term "end of life" was coined, he said, as a way of describing the end of a career.
Two years later, in 2011, the Great East Japan Earthquake occurred.
Many people have come to realize the reality that death can come suddenly, and there are more people who are preparing for their own end and the end of their lives.
It's been more than 10 years since then.
The new coronavirus pandemic that has swept the world has not yet subsided.
Prices have risen due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and electricity bills have skyrocketed this winter.
On the other hand, wages are not rising as much as the current high prices, and many people are worried about the future.
On the other hand, the time when funeral expenses, care expenses, and burial expenses could be shared by relatives and friends is long gone, and nowadays it is rare for a single child to exist.
There is also the dilemma that while life expectancy has increased significantly, the risk of dementia and care dependency increases as we age.
It is worth bearing in mind that the rise in social anxiety is also a factor in the fact that the end of life is becoming a permanent fixture.
Either way, nobody wants to put too much pressure on their partner or children.
"Dying with dignity" is a popular key phrase, but it is not something that should be taken too far.
Rather than keeping your wishes and preferences to yourself, it's a good idea to discuss them with your family and make arrangements in advance.

"Dear Prime Minister, the Breakwater of Life" from Tōjinbō, a book published by the NPO organization "Heart-touching Collection and Editorial Office"
"Dear Prime Minister, 'Breakwater of Life' from Tōjinbō" is the 10th book that they have published at their own expense.
The book has been featured in newspapers across the country, and many readers have sent in their own impressions.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share the contents of the "social and structural" environmental issues that are the cause of suicide in Japan, which were directly heard from those who attempted suicide, and to create a "society that is good to live in" with the hope of creating a "society that is good to live in."

We have been patrolling the waterfront of Tōjinbō, Fukui Prefecture, which is called a suicide spot, for 18 years and 10 months to prevent suicide, and we continue to support those who have been discovered and protected by us to re-start their lives.

The book is a summary of the problems heard from the 784 people (as of 2/6) that have been protected so far, and it makes the following seven points to the Prime Minister about the national policies necessary to prevent suicide.
(1) Suicide prevention activities are "life-saving" activities.
(2) Behind suicide, there is a mountain of "human rights violations".
(3) Suicide victims are victims of social and structural organized crime.
(4) The administration treats citizens living outside the jurisdiction as "outsiders" and gives them cold treatment.
(5) Depression and other mental disorders are medicated and treated as "accidents" even when they result in suicide.
(6) "Duty of care" in high-risk suicide areas is forgotten and commercialism is rampant.

(7) The parts of the teachings of new religious movements that cannot be scientifically proven are fraudulent, and the behavior of threatening the future and providing money to force the other party to provide money is extortion.
Religious groups that engage in these criminal acts of "fraud and extortion" should be exposed and eliminated.

So, we have received some very heartfelt letters from people who have bought the book, saying things like "I am deeply moved by the strength of the people who are working on this," "The former police officer is a true police officer," and "What a saint, to support others as if they were his own family, even though they are not his own family."
I saw the photo in the newspaper and tears came to my eyes, "What do I think...?"
I hear that suicides are increasing among people who are being driven to the brink by the Corona disaster.
It's really sad.
Everyone is who they are.
I hope that we can live in a society where we can enjoy our own lives.
I felt respect and gratitude towards all the staff who are doing their best to support those who are carrying the burden of wanting to die.
I think this is a very demanding activity for both the mind and the body, so please take care of yourself and continue to make your voice heard.
Thank you.
kashi
I hope that everyone who reads this will become a gatekeeper of life in their own region.

Introducing the pioneers of plant research, including Hayachine Mountain collection materials, in the exhibition "Hachimaki" at the City General Cultural Property Center. | Iwanichi Online, Iwate Nippo

An exhibition titled "People who introduced the flowers of Hayachine - A small history of Hayachine plant research" which features the pioneers who laid the foundation for the plant research of Hayachine, which is known as a treasure trove of alpine plants, is being held at the Iwate Prefectural General Cultural Property Center in Ohasama, Hanamaki City until the 12th.
The exhibition features 124 items, including valuable specimens collected by the pioneers, and introduces the footprints of the pioneers involved in the study of plants on Mt. Hayachine.

The study of plants on Mt. Hayachine began with the Russian botanist Karl Johann Maximowitsch (1827-1891), who came to Japan in the late Edo period, and Sugawa Chonosuke (1842-1925), who collected plants under Maximowitsch's guidance, who was born in Shiwa Town.
Maximo-Wichit, who was not allowed to freely walk around the country for foreigners, asked Sugawa to collect, and continued his research for three years with Yokohama and Nagasaki as his base.
After Maksimowitch returned to Russia, Sukawa continued to support his research, which led to the publication of the Hayachine's unique Primula macrocarpa, Sanguisorba obtusa, and Aruncus dioicus.

Later, modern botanist Makino Fujitaro (1862-1957) published "Bistorta hayachinensis" and "Kobanotsume-kusa" in 1903 (Meiji 36) based on the collections of local researchers, and "Katoana" in 1905 (Meiji 38) after he himself climbed Hayachine Mountain and discovered and named it.
From the exhibited materials, it can be seen that many researchers have revealed valuable alpine plants.

The exhibition also introduces the work of Shimura Masanosuke (1874-1948), who was a botanist and accompanied the survey of natural monuments in 1927, and Tamakawa Shichiro (1914-1988), who worked as a museum curator at the Hasama Mountain Museum and also contributed to the publication of "Plants of Hakihone."

"There is a lot of research and human connections behind the name of each plant on Mt. Hayachine," said Yoshida, a researcher at the center. "We can trace the connections between researchers from local areas to the whole country."

The exhibition is divided into four chapters, with the first chapter focusing on the history and beliefs of Mt. Fuji, and the second chapter using the research of Heinrich Eduard Naumann (1854-1927), a German geologist who laid the foundation for Japanese geology, to spotlight the characteristics of Mt. Fuji from a geological perspective.

Due to the influence of heavy snow, JR lines in the prefecture were suspended on the 10th, including the Kitakami, Hanawa, Yamada, Oofuna, Kamaishi, and Hachinohe lines.

According to the JR Sendai Branch Office, of these, the Kitakami Line saw three trains between Kitakami and Yokote suspended, affecting around 80 users, while the Ofunato Line saw four trains between Ichinoseki and Kesennuma suspended, affecting around 280 users.
The branch office announced the schedule for the JR Azukibashi Line on the 11th, stating that heavy snow was expected.
The Kitakami Line from Fujinomiya to Yokote had trains from the start of service until around 9:00 a.m. cancelled in both directions, and some trains on the Kitakami - Fujinomiya line were cancelled.

The Ofunato Line will have no service from Ichinoseki to Kesennuma from the morning until 5:30 pm, and the Kamaishi Line will have no service from Morioka to Kamaishi from the morning until noon, and from the morning until 11:00 am.
The Tohoku line will also suspend some trains on the up and down lines.
The schedule may be changed depending on the weather conditions.

Idlib province in northwestern Syria, which was hit by the earthquake = Early morning of the 9th (Provided by local residents, Kyodo)

[Gaziantep, Turkey] According to the authorities of Turkey and neighboring Syria, which were affected by the earthquake that originated in southern Turkey, the number of confirmed deaths exceeded 21,000 in both countries on the 9th.
Rescue efforts to save survivors from collapsed buildings and other structures in the midst of the harsh cold have become more difficult as time passes.
Searches are continuing in the affected areas.
The United Nations said on the 9th that it had delivered aid to the northwestern Syrian province of Idlib for the first time since the earthquake on the 6th, through the Turkish border.
Idlib province was the last stronghold of anti-regime rebels fighting against Assad's rule in Syria's civil war, and there were concerns that international aid would not reach them.
Rescue efforts using heavy machinery are continuing at both countries' disaster sites, but they are facing difficulties.
Many are believed to be buried under the rubble and the death toll is likely to rise.
Turkish authorities have confirmed 17,674 deaths in Turkey.
The death toll in Syria, which is now over 3,000, has surpassed the 17,000 killed in the 1999 earthquake in northwestern Turkey.

It is expected to provide around 800 people.

Second renewable energy introduction and goal consultation Amami Airport 2nd decarbonization promotion council | Society & Economy | Nankai Daily
Promotion Council for Decarbonization of Amami Airport Held Discussions on Decarbonization = On September 9, Kasari, Amami City

The "Amami Airport Decarbonization Promotion Council" (Chairman: Takahashi, Chief of the Construction Section of the Okinawa Prefectural Okinawa Island Office, 13 members) which is made up of the prefecture and airlines that use the airport, held its second meeting at the airport on the 9th.
All members, including online members, attended.
They exchanged opinions on setting targets for decarbonization and introducing renewable energy, with solar power generation as the main focus.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has set a total goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions at each airport by 46% (compared to 2013) by 2050, with the aim of achieving zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 under the "Carbon Neutral" initiative.
In response, the council held its first meeting last November, and is aiming to establish plans ahead of other airports on other islands in the prefecture.
The second meeting was held in private, as with the first meeting.
After the meeting, Atō Chairman, who responded to the press, said that the meeting confirmed the greenhouse gas emissions of the airport.
They said that they are moving forward with the guidelines set by the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism to set goals and introduce renewable energy.
According to the distribution materials, the CO2 emissions from the airport's equipment and vehicles in the 13th year, which serves as the benchmark, was 1476 tons (excluding aircraft).

Of these, the emissions from the airport terminal building and seven other facilities, such as lighting and air conditioning, account for about 90 percent, followed by air navigation lights at 84 tons and airport vehicles at 71 tons.
The council will discuss reducing the emissions of these facilities and vehicles.
"We are at a turning point," said Ando. "The direction of the committee members is in agreement, and I would like to firmly compile the interim report."
In the future, the plan will be formulated after hearing opinions on the interim report at the third meeting and the final report at the fourth meeting.
"Reverse Real Estate" Okinoyara Branch Office Opens to Bring People to the Island, and People Wanting to Rent Houses Collect Landlords | Society & Economy | Nankai Daily
Opening event to deepen understanding of "sakasama real estate" through talk sessions = August 8, Chinacho

[Okinoerabu General Affairs Bureau] The Okinoerabu branch office opening event for "Sakasama Real Estate," a real estate website that matches people who want to rent out vacant houses or shops with landlords, was held on the 8th at the community center "entaku" in Chinacho.
The operating company explained the outline of the service through a talk session.
Tsukinoba (Rishiri, Hokkaido) President Director, Okubo Masahiro, said, "If we do this on Okinoerabu Island, we can create a movement that brings people to the island and creates a flow."
Unlike conventional real estate, Sakasama Real Estate works by displaying information on people who want to rent and then contacting landlords, who then make their own agreements.

As a proof of concept to uncover potential vacant homes and build relationships through vacant homes, the service was launched in June 2020, and is operated by On-Co Co. Ltd. (headquarters Mie Prefecture).
The opening of the branch office is the seventh in the region of Kyushu.
It is the first time in the country for an island.
About 20 people participated in the event, including On-Co and Tsukinohara staff, town hall employees from Wakkabara and Shimane, and local residents.

Okubo, the representative director, explained the process of opening the branch office, saying, "As the movement to bring people from the mainland is becoming more active, I thought that if we could utilize vacant houses and vacant stores, the town and the island could become even more lively."

"I want to help people who have properties on the island and people who want to do something by connecting them and helping them to carry out their efforts, even if it's just one property and one person."

On-Co representative, Mizutani Gakushi, said, "We need to take care of each empty house and discuss with the locals what they want to do with the area, who they want to come and what they want to base their decisions on."
"The more people connect with each other, the more information will be gathered," he said, calling for the participation of islanders in discussions and cooperation in providing information.

For example, you can get a white solar LED garden light for around 1,500 yen at a hardware store (the latest ones are very bright and have 6 lamps).

Persona songs are good!
Persona 3 gets to the ED.
I played up to 5.
Persona 4 is complete on Vita.
What you can do is the same as in the previous Persona 4.
The story is non-existent and feels shorter than the previous game.
The music is really nice!
Just listening to it makes me feel good!
Persona 3 characters were the first to be HD-ized, so I was moved when I first saw them.
I guess Seon-hwa looks like a hunk (laugh) Persona 5 is beautiful from the start, so the freshness is not that great... If you think that way, then 3 is a better deal.
As a game, I found 5 easier to play than 3.
Persona 3 is blue based, so it was hard to see the backgrounds when they were dark.
5 is mainly bright colors like red and yellow, so it's easy to see through the background.
With the abundance of assist features, I think even those who are not good at games can enjoy playing.
The challenge feature is a nice touch for those who are more experienced with the game.
The triple pack comes with soundtracks, and not just a few tracks, but a solid 4 discs, so if you like the music in Persona, I recommend this.

It gets heavy in the evening.
I used it on a SIM free iPhone 7s.

At first, I didn’t know how to do it after arriving in Korea and pointing my SIM, so I asked a woman at the SK counter at Gimpo Airport (by going to settings > mobile communication > communication options and turning data roaming on), and it worked out fine.
The instructions that came with the product didn't seem to matter much...?
The thing is, I've been having a hard time getting 3G in the Gimpo airport area, which is notorious for bad reception.
When I went out into the city, it became 4G.
In the evening and night, the communication was sometimes very heavy, but I think I was reaching the maximum limit of how many MB I could use in a day.
